From the last livestream of 2022, Tom and Dominic discuss the decline of Christianity in the UK, whether it is a good idea to psychoanalyze historical figures, and the importance of giving their World Cup episodes fantastic titles.

To watch the livestream, click the link below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MZYmjA13aqg

title: Switzerland: Calvin's Cancel Culture
cleaned_description: Today, Tom and Dominic are in 16th century Calvinist Geneva, where Michael Servetus is being condemned for heresy. Execution, imprisonment, treachery, and public burnings all feature in this story, which bears unusual similarities to the times we live in today.

title: Portugal: The Carnation Revolution
cleaned_description: In today's World Cup episode, Tom and Dominic return to the history of Portugal to discuss military coups, the defense of dictatorship, Castro in Cuba, and the creation of a post-Salazar state.

title: Senegal: The Door of No Return
cleaned_description: In today's episode, Tom and Dominic discuss the Senegalese island of Gorée and its relationship with the transatlantic slave trade. They explore both the history and mythology of the "House of Slaves," which still stands today as a vestige of human exploitation.

title: Belgium: History's Greatest Artist
cleaned_description: Who is the greatest artist of all time? Join Tom and Dominic as Belgian historian Bart van Loo puts forward the case for the hyper-realistic and highly influential art of early Northern Renaissance painter Jan van Eyck.

title: Poland: Copernicus, the Dragon and the Salt Mine
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic as they explore the seven wonders of Poland. Hear all about Krakus the dragon-slayer, the Wieliczka Salt Mine, "Kaiser soup," the influence of Oriental fashion, and much more.

title: Ghana: The Ashanti Empire
cleaned_description:
On today's World Cup episode, Tom and Dominic discuss the Ashanti Empire. 

Tune in to hear about the Anglo-Ashanti wars, the Golden Stool, the role of Robert Baden-Powell, and much more.

title: RIHC: Podwashing, Tom’s opera, and Pixar
cleaned_description: In this week's bonus, Tom and Dominic discuss recent news, including revelations about a fake Roman emperor. They also continue to react to the World Cup episodes and delve into Tom's feelings about Pixar movies.

title: Brazil: The Last Emperor
cleaned_description: As promised during the Portugal mini-series, Tom and Dominic are returning to Brazil to discuss its history post-independence. This episode will focus on the Brazilian Empire, particularly Emperor Pedro II. How did this boy, who acceded to the throne at six years old, come to receive a French state funeral in front of 300,000 Parisians in the pouring rain?

title: Wales: The Roar of the Red Dragon
cleaned_description: What are the origins of Wales? And how do the Welsh define themselves against Englishness? As England plays Wales in the World Cup today, Tom and Dominic are joined by Martin Johnes, Professor of History at the University of Swansea, to explore the age-old rivalry between the two nations.

title: South Korea: The Riddle of Hwang Jini
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic on their journey to the 16th century Korean peninsula as they discuss Hwang Jini—a gisaeng, poet, and entertainer—and her everlasting impact on Korean culture. Dubbed by Tom the 'poetic Emma Hamilton,' the story of Hwang Jini takes us through the Diamond Mountains, Buddhism, Confucianism, 16th-century Korean social class, and much more.

title: Saudi Arabia: The Mystery of the Kaaba
cleaned_description:
Join Tom and Dominic for their World Cup episode on Saudi Arabia, where they discuss 'the most famous structure in global Islam' - the Kaaba in Mecca. 

Tune in to hear about the Prophet Mohammed, Abdul Malik, and the origins of the most sacred site in Islam.

title: Mexico: Day of the Dead
cleaned_description: On the Day of the Dead, you eat pan de muerto and exchange calaveras with your friends. This celebration is often claimed to have its roots in ancient Aztec traditions of human sacrifice. But is any of this true? Join Tom and Dominic to find out.

title: USA vs England: The 200-Year Rivalry
cleaned_description:
In today's World Cup special, Anglo-American relations are at their most tense as the USA and England take to the football/soccer pitch.

Join Tom and Dominic as they take a retrospective look at this 200-year love-hate relationship. From the War of 1812 to Charles Dickens, all the way up to Beatlemania and James Bond—buckle up to discover the historical drama underpinning today's battle in Al Bayt Stadium.

title: Tunisia: Dido of Carthage
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic as they tell the story of the tragic heroine of Virgil’s Aeneid - Dido of Carthage. They discuss the origins of Carthage, recite top Latin phrases, and are joined by Juliette Pochin for a beautiful rendition of Dido’s Lament.

title: RIHC: Tom in Romania, multiculturalism, and the World Cup
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic in this week’s bonus as they discuss Tom’s trip to Romania, which included a visit to the ancient Dacian capital, Sarmizegetusa. They also explore the tensions inherent in the western criticisms of Qatar and share listener responses to the World Cup episodes so far.

title: Uruguay: The Tupamaros
cleaned_description: In 1963, with the influence of the Cuban Revolution strong in South America, the left-wing guerrilla group the Tupamaros emerged. Listen to tales of kidnappings, shootings, imprisonment, and torture in the Tupamaros' quest for political power.

title: Croatia: The Man Who Saved The Roman Empire
cleaned_description:
"In conditions of chaos, people from outside the Roman social elite can rise to the top."

Join Tom and Dominic for their World Cup episode on Croatia, where they discuss the extraordinary life of the Emperor Diocletian. They talk about the Crisis of the Third Century, the Roman 'sidebar of shame', the crisis in Gaul, Roman Brexit, the foundations of the Byzantine Empire, and the best fact Dominic has heard in the World Cup series so far.

title: Iran: England - 'The Little Satan'
cleaned_description:
On the day of England vs. Iran, Tom and Dominic are joined by friend of the show, Ali Ansari, to discuss Anglo-Iranian relations.

Tune in to hear stories of freemasons, early Iranian analysis of Tories and Whigs, the Anglo-Persian War, Salman Rushdie's fatwa, the ancestor of British Petroleum, and why Iran still sees England as a fox-like, 'little Satan'.

title: Costa Rica: Civil War
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic as they continue the World Cup series by discussing the Costa Rican Civil War. This event is filled with tremendous characters, including the historian-cum-president Teodoro Picado Michalski, José Figueres Ferrer who abolished the army, and the infamous Dr. Valverde.

title: Australia: The Mystery of the Somerton Man
cleaned_description: In today’s Australian-themed World Cup episode, Tom leads us through the incredible true story of the Somerton Man, a murder mystery that involves an Adelaide beach, Persian poetry, and unexpected marriage. All will be revealed…

title: Germany: The White Rose
cleaned_description:
“Since the conquest of Poland, 300,000 Jews have been murdered in this country in the most bestial way ... The German people slumber on in dull, stupid sleep and encourage the fascist criminals. Each wants to be exonerated of guilt, each one continues on his way with the most placid, calm conscience. But he cannot be exonerated; he is guilty, guilty, guilty!” - Leaflet from the White Rose resistance movement, 1942.

In today’s episode on Germany, Dominic tells us the heroic story of five German students who founded a non-violent protest group during the most oppressive days of Nazi control.

title: Qatar: A History
cleaned_description:
It is finally here. Tom and Dominic are embarking upon their World Cup themed extravaganza. Every day they will be releasing a new episode, each one based upon a different country that is competing in the tournament. 32 days, 32 countries, 32 episodes—fasten your seatbelts and enjoy the ride.

First up is Qatar. How did this tiny country in the Middle East come to play such a prominent role in world affairs? Oil money, controlling the narrative, and western security are all part of the story.

title: RIHC: Athelstans, Alfred and Anglo-Scottish relations
description: Join Tom and Dominic as they discuss their recent Athelstan party and live shows, the impending World Cup mega-series, Anglo-Saxon abolitionists, Californian cricket, and much more.
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic as they discuss their recent Athelstan party and live shows, the impending World Cup mega-series, Anglo-Saxon abolitionists, Californian cricket, and much more.

title: The World Cup: The Falklands, despots, and corruption (Ep 3)
cleaned_description: In their last episode on the World Cup, Tom and Dominic are joined by Gary Lineker. They discuss England playing Argentina in the 1986 World Cup in the wake of the Falklands War, the globalization of the competition that began with USA 1994, and the corruption that surrounds the upcoming tournament in Qatar.

title: The World Cup: Post-war reconciliation, Brazilian dictatorship, and North Koreans in Middlesbrough (Ep 2)
cleaned_description: Welcome to the second episode of The Rest Is History's definitive guide to the history of the FIFA World Cup. In this episode, Tom and Dominic discuss the 1953 Match of the Century, post-war reconciliation, Dutch naked pool parties, medicals at NASA, Pickles the dog, and more.

title: The World Cup: British Imperialism, South American rivalries, and Mussolini (Ep 1)
cleaned_description:
Welcome to The Rest Is History's definitive guide to the history of the FIFA World Cup, which looks past the football and uncovers the personalities, geopolitics, and drama behind the tournament.

In the first of three episodes, Tom and Dominic debate whether the global game is a product of British imperialism, vicious South American rivalries, Bolivians playing in berets, the looming shadow of the Second World War, Mussolini, Hitler, and more.

title: History's coming home... (preview)
cleaned_description:
Forget the football; the next month's entertainment is coming from The Rest is History!

Join Tom and Dominic over the coming weeks as they embark on their colossal festival of world history. To mark the FIFA World Cup, they are bringing you an episode on every single country taking part in the competition. From the Costa Rican Civil War to courtesans in South Korea, via the White Rose movement in Nazi Germany, there is a historical tale for everyone.

To set this all up, on Monday, Tom and Dominic begin an epic three-parter on the history of the World Cup, using the tournament as a vehicle for understanding global political and social history.

Join The Rest Is History Club (www.restishistorypod.com) for ad-free listening to the full archive, weekly bonus episodes, live-streamed shows, and access to an exclusive chatroom community.

title: RIHC: Vikings, Anglo-Saxons and videogames
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic as they celebrate two years of The Rest is History podcast! They reflect on their favorite episodes gone by and discuss exciting new episodes to come.

title: Alfred the Great: Return of the King (Ep 2)
cleaned_description: Battling with the expanding power of the Vikings, listen to Tom and Dominic discover how King Alfred the Great earned his name in the second installment of our two-part series on England's Founding Father.

title: Alfred the Great: Fury of the Vikings (Ep 1)
cleaned_description:
Alfred the Great is under invasion from the Vikings.

Join Tom and Dominic as they discuss Alfred's anointment by the Pope in Rome, his duality as both a fearsome warrior and a man of poetry, plus his unbelievable escape from a Christmas ambush from Viking invaders.

Dominic's book, 'Adventures in Time: Fury of the Vikings', is available to buy now in all good bookshops.

title: RIHC: Treason, Trafalgar and Teaching (livestream)
cleaned_description:
Tom and Dominic are finally together again for this week's bonus episode. During their livestream, they discuss Dominic's recent visit to Istanbul, the teaching of history in schools, Monty, Patton, and much more. 

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Treason in Modern Britain (Ep 2)
cleaned_description:
Join Tom and Dominic for the second part of their exploration of the history of treason. How has the 1351 treason act impacted Britain and the world since the 17th century? This will be answered as they discuss seismic events such as the trial of Charles I, American independence, and the Easter Rising.

Treason: People, Power and Plot opens at The National Archives on 5th November and runs until 6th April. It is free to all. For more information and to delve deeper, please visit nationalarchives.gov.uk/treason.

title: Medieval Treason (Ep 1)
cleaned_description:
Join Tom and Dominic at the National Archives as they explore the history of treason in Britain, going right back to the 1351 treason act. How has treason changed since its inception? Why are traitors hanged, drawn, and quartered? What impact did the Reformation have upon treason? As these questions are answered, the story will interlink with some of the biggest characters in British history: Richard III, Henry VIII, James I, and more!

Treason: People, Power and Plot opens at The National Archives on 5th November and runs until 6th April. It is free to all. For all information and to delve deeper, please visit nationalarchives.gov.uk/treason.

title: Monty & Patton vs. the Nazis
cleaned_description: Do commanders matter? Were the British generals effective or "foppish"? How did the Allies rebound from huge losses such as the Battle of Dunkirk to victories like El Alamein and D-Day? Tom and Dominic are joined by Al Murray to discuss all this and more, following the release of Al’s new book, *Command: How the Allies Learned to Win the Second World War*.

title: RIHC: Trafalgar, Julia Gillard, and Producer Jack
cleaned_description:
In a Rest Is History first, this podcast features a historic personality who has actually been the subject of one of our shows!

In the latest bonus episode, Tom is joined by former Australian PM Julia Gillard to discuss Trafalgar, recording episodes in Venice, and the Edinburgh Festival.

title: The Fall of Liz Truss
cleaned_description:
After just 45 days, Liz Truss has resigned.

Join Tom and Dominic for this special episode to discuss her place in history. Is she Britain's worst ever Prime Minister? Is this the worst crisis in post-war British history? How does she compare to Gordian I? All will be answered.

title: Trafalgar: Victory (Ep 3)
cleaned_description: In this final episode, Tom and Dominic discuss the legendary Battle of Trafalgar. Despite being outnumbered and facing the largest ship in the world, Nelson took the battle to the French and Spanish forces. With the swell on his side, Nelson’s brave leadership from the deck of the Victory gave the British one of their most famous military successes. Join Tom and Dominic as they take you through the battle, Nelson’s death, and its legacy.

title: Trafalgar: Countdown to Annihilation (Ep 2)
cleaned_description: In the second episode of Tom and Dominic's Trafalgar trilogy, the stakes could not be higher. They discuss Napoleon's plan to invade Britain and the possible repercussions if he did, the developments in naval technology and their implications for the British and Spanish/French allies, and Nelson's life, legacy, and strategy to "annihilate the enemy."

title: Trafalgar: A World at War (Ep 1)
cleaned_description: Was the Battle of Trafalgar the most decisive battle of the 19th century? Join Tom and Dominic as they embark on a three-part series discussing this incredible conflict between the British Royal Navy and the combined fleets of the French and Spanish navies. In this episode, they discuss the distrust between the standing army and the Royal Navy, the technology used for the first time during Trafalgar, and the martyr-like status of Horatio Nelson, who led the British to victory.

title: French History on Film
cleaned_description: Tom and Dominic welcome film critic Muriel Zagha to discuss the home of cinema, France, and its history through ten films, spanning from Vercingétorix to Vichy. Featuring Jean Renoir, Isabelle Adjani, Louis de Funès, and many more.

title: RIHC: The Tomless Trilogy - Part III
cleaned_description: In this week's bonus episode, Dominic discusses Radio 4's 'In Our Time', the Crimean War, his least favorite Beatle, and the plight of History teachers.

title: RIHC: Spain, Churchill, and Producer Dom
cleaned_description: With Tom away, Dominic is joined by Dom to discuss Spanish history, the Young Churchill episodes, and whether Kwasi Kwarteng has a historical parallel.

title: Young Churchill: Prisoner and Fugitive (Ep 3)
cleaned_description: In the final installment of our series on Young Churchill, learn how Churchill escaped a prisoner of war camp in the Boer War, becoming an imperialist hero. Discover how Churchill sought shelter in rat-infested hideaways, escaped in the tight consignment of a train, and how a simple hair appointment almost blew his cover.

title: Young Churchill: Soldier of Empire (Ep 2)
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic in the second episode of our mini-series on Young Churchill as they dive into his imperial exploits. From Cuba to Sudan, they explore his obsession with adventure, the ambiguities that existed within his own moral universe, and his swashbuckling prose.

title: Young Churchill: Born to Lead (Ep 1)
cleaned_description:
‘The child is the father of the man.’

In the first episode of this mini-series on Young Churchill, Tom and Dominic explore the early life of Winston Churchill. They discuss the cruelty of his parents, his deeply imbued sense of destiny, and the razor-sharp wit of the future Prime Minister.

title: The Regency Revolution
cleaned_description:
How were the bonnets, corsets, and empire line dresses of the Regency period expressive of a revolutionary era?

In this episode, Tom Holland and Dominic Sandbrook are joined by Hilary Davidson to discuss fashion in early 19th century Britain. Diving into the world of Jane Austen, they look to understand how the unprecedented changes in style were driven by the social, cultural, and political changes of the time.

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: RIHC: Marilyn Tomroe, Hilary Mantel and Producer Tony
description: For this weeks bonus episode, Dominic is joined by Executive Producer Tony Pastor to discuss the reaction to Tom's Marilyn Monroe impersonation whilst he is away... They also discuss the sad passing of Hilary Mantel and her incredible body of work, Tony's experiences in Vietnam and an 'indiscreet' story about Roy Keane.
cleaned_description: In this week's bonus episode, Dominic discusses the reaction to Tom's Marilyn Monroe impersonation while he is away. They also reflect on the sad passing of Hilary Mantel and her incredible body of work, as well as Tony's experiences in Vietnam and an 'indiscreet' story about Roy Keane.

title: Marilyn Monroe
cleaned_description: Actress, singer, model, and sex symbol Marilyn Monroe has long been associated with old-school Hollywood glamour and American pop culture. But why is she worth studying historically? Join Tom and Dominic as they discuss Marilyn's relationship to the Mafia, JFK, the Korean War, and her persisting relevance today.

youtu.be/UDqTfsTyKJc

title: China and World War II - Part 2
cleaned_description:
Tom and Dominic welcome back special guest Rana Mitter to discuss China's position during World War Two. 

This episode covers the Rape of Nanjing by Japanese forces, the military tactic of flooding the Yellow River, the deal between Chinese Nationalist Wang Jin Wei and Japan, and the unlikely pairing of 'Vinegar Joe' Stilwell and Chiang Kai-shek.

title: China and World War II - Part 1
cleaned_description:
Friend of the show Rana Mitter joins Tom and Dominic this week to discuss the role of China in the Second World War.

In the first of two episodes, Rana, Tom, and Dominic cover the fall of the last Emperor and the establishment of a Chinese Republic in 1912, the Opium Wars, warlords, and the Kuomintang uniting China.

Plus, tune in to find out why Rana argues that the Second World War actually began in 1937.

title: Germans Behaving Badly
cleaned_description: Why is modern society so self-obsessed? The answer may be found in a group of late 18th century German rebels, including the writer Goethe and playwright Friedrich Schiller. Andrea Wulf joins Dominic and Tom in today's episode to discuss the rebels' progressive (and often scandalous) lives and her new book, 'Magnificent Rebels: The First Romantics and the Invention of the Self'.

title: RIHC: It's a Royal Knockout, Queen Elizabeth II, and Portugal
cleaned_description: In the latest RIHC bonus episode, Tom and Dominic discuss Queen Elizabeth II, Portugal, and the incredible spectacle that was the 1987 TV one-off, 'It's a Royal Knockout'.

title: The Loch Ness Monster
cleaned_description:
Does the Loch Ness Monster exist? When was the first mention of it recorded in history? And who are the people who have claimed to have seen it?

Join Tom and Dominic as they discuss how a few 'sightings' of a mysterious creature took the world by storm.

title: Queen Elizabeth II - part 2
description: In February 1952, on the death of her father King George VI, the 25-year-old Elizabeth became Queen. During her long reign she was served by 15 Prime Ministers and met an extraordinary array of people. Dominic Sandbrook and Tom Holland here examine her 70 years as Queen of the United Kingdom & 14 other countries, and head of the Commonwealth.

title: Queen Elizabeth II - part 1
description: The death of the Queen at the age of 96 brings to an end seven decades of her reign over Britain and the Commonwealth. In the first of a two-part series, Dominic Sandbrook and Tom Holland look back at the early years of Elizabeth’s life, leading up to her coronation.

Join Tom and Dominic as they discuss the Portuguese setting sail for far-flung reaches of the world, its relationship with Philip II of Spain, and the impact of Vasco Da Gama.

title: Portugal: On the Edge of the World (Ep 1)

title: The Lord of the Rings
cleaned_description:
Written in stages between 1937 and 1949, The Lord of the Rings is one of the best-selling books ever written, with over 150 million copies sold.

Join Tom and Dominic in the second of two episodes on the life and work of J.R.R. Tolkien, where they discuss the themes of encroaching industrialization, the air defenses of Mordor, and whether the Scouring of the Shire was an allegory for post-war Attlee Britain.

title: J.R.R. Tolkien
cleaned_description:
John Ronald Reuel Tolkien is one of the most prestigious authors in modern history, best known for writing The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings.

In the first of two episodes, Tom and Dominic explore Tolkien's childhood, his relationship with religion, and the impact that the rapidly changing English countryside had on the creation of Middle Earth.

title: RIHC: Cambridge, Crusaders, and Tolkien
cleaned_description:
Oxford and Cambridge, drug smuggling camels, and the upcoming episodes on Tolkien.

Join Tom and Dominic for the latest RIHC bonus episode.

title: Roman Holidays (Ep 4)
cleaned_description:
Grand villas on the Bay of Naples, engraving names on Egyptian singing statues, and sightseeing tours of Biblical sights in the Levant.

The fourth and final episode of this series explores Roman holidays. Join Tom and Dominic as they discuss the destinations and activities of the ancient holidaying world.

title: Sun, Sea, and Sex (Ep 3)
cleaned_description: The rise and fall of Butlin's, Benidorm and Franco, class, package holidays, bikinis, mass tourism, and sunbathing. The third episode in our holiday series has it all - join Tom and Dominic as they discuss the history of modern holidays in the post-First World War era.

title: RIHC: Salman Rushdie, classified files, and trigger warnings
cleaned_description: In the latest RIHC bonus episode, Tom and Dominic discuss Salman Rushdie, cricketer Carlos Brathwaite's appreciation of the Pigeons episode, and Dominic's love for trigger warnings.

title: Introducing Empire with William Dalrymple
description:
Today's feed drop features friend of the show William Dalrymple discussing his new podcast, Empire, which he hosts alongside Anita Anand.

How do empires rise? Why do they fall? And how have they shaped the world around us today?

This new show explores the stories, personalities and events of empire over the course of history.

The first series looks at the British in India, covering The East India Company, the Raj, Gandhi, Independence and Partition.

In the opening episode, William and Anita discuss the rise of The East India Company, exploring how a small corporation with only a handful of employees came to rule India. The episode begins with the birth of the Company in Tudor England and culminates with Robert Clive and the Battle of Plassey.

Listen to the second episode of Empire right now:
Apple - apple.co/3bVP1Xi
Spotify - spoti.fi/3zX2hmG

Wars, disease, and legacy.

title: Justinian: Making Rome Great Again (Ep 2)
cleaned_description:
The Riot that destroyed a city and almost brought down an Emperor...

In the second part of our trilogy, Tom and Dominic discuss the Nika riots in the early part of Justinian's reign and how he positioned himself as the defender of Christendom against the Persian Empire in the East.

title: Theodora: Empress of Byzantium (Ep 1)
cleaned_description:
In the first episode of a three-part series, Tom and Dominic dive into the incredible story of Justinian and Theodora. 

Tune in for an engaging introduction to the powerful Byzantine empress, the collapse of the Western half of the Roman Empire, and a deep dive into the great city of Constantinople.

title: Plague and the decline of the Roman Empire
cleaned_description:
Tom and Dominic are joined by friend of the show Kyle Harper to discuss how pandemics and disease played a far greater role in the decline of the Roman Empire than previously understood.

On the show, Kyle, Dominic, and Tom discuss life expectancy, how the Roman Empire was ‘bad for people’s health,' the Antonine Plague, and more.

Listen to our previous episodes with Kyle:
146. Disease vs. the rise of civilisation
147. Disease, the New World and modern pandemics

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Pigeons
cleaned_description:
‘If it became necessary immediately to discard every line and method of communications used on the front, except one, and it were left to me to select that one method, I should unhesitatingly choose the pigeons,’ wrote Major General Fowler, Chief of Signals and Communications of the British Army, after the First World War.

On today's podcast, Tom and Dominic are joined by Gordon Corera, the BBC's Security Correspondent and author of 'Operation Columba: The Secret Pigeon Service', to discuss the often under-appreciated role of pigeons throughout the course of history.

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

On the public feed, we'll release an episode daily, from Monday to Friday. 

In this episode, Tom and Dominic focus on two very different historical places in London's past, discussing Barking Abbey and the 2i's Coffee Bar. 

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Londinium (Ep 1)
description:
Welcome to the first episode in our new mini-series: LONDON WEEK.

On the public feed, we'll release an episode daily, from Monday to Friday. However, as a friend of the show, you get them ALL at once!

Ep 1 'Londinium' and Ep 4 'Haunted London' are live pods we recorded on location earlier this year. 'Places', 'People', and 'Moments' are three accompanying episodes that Tom and Dominic recorded in order to dive deeper into London's past.

Londinium:
Amid the sounds of building sites and ambulance sirens, Tom and Dominic march across the bridges and snake down the alleyways of London. In this special live episode, they uncover the Roman roots of the capital city, tracing its journey from desolate mudflats to a sprawling beacon of civilisation. 

Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producers: Jack Davenport + Tony Pastor

@TheRestHistory

title: George Orwell
cleaned_description:
George Orwell is one of the most celebrated novelists, essayists, and journalists in modern British history.

Tom and Dominic are joined by Robert Colls, Professor Emeritus of History at De Montfort University, to discuss the life and legacy of the man who wrote Nineteen Eighty-Four, Animal Farm, and Homage to Catalonia.

title: RIHC: Sweden, haircuts, and British democracy
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic for this week's bonus episode, where they discuss the legacy of the American Civil War, British democracy in light of recent events, and Dominic’s new holiday haircut.

title: Historical Love Island: THE WINNER
cleaned_description:
Historical Love Island has swept the nation and the podcasting world since Monday, when four couples made it to the final: General Custer & Lola Montez, Lord Byron & Sporus, Stanley Baldwin & Theodora, and Jimmy Carter & Olympias.

Fans voted for their favourite historical pair - but which couple did Rest Is History listeners crown victorious? Listen to this special episode as Tom and Dominic announce the winner.

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Historical Love Island
cleaned_description:
The Love Island phenomenon is sweeping the nation, so Tom Holland and Dominic Sandbrook are joined by Tom's daughter, Katy Holland, to create a ‘villa’ made up of historical figures. Who will lovable nice-boy Jimmy Carter ‘couple up’ with? Will Judas Iscariot and Stanley Baldwin get along?

After listening on Monday morning, vote on The Rest Is History's Love Island poll for your favorite historical couple. A special bonus episode will be released on Wednesday, July 13, to announce and assess the winners and losers.

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: The Last Days of Boris Johnson
cleaned_description:
Boris Johnson has resigned.

In a special episode of The Rest Is History, Tom and Dominic dissect the tumultuous last few days in British politics, with references and comparisons to Roman emperors, Margaret Thatcher, and other characters from modern and ancient history.

title: Gone with the Wind
cleaned_description:
"There was a land of cavaliers and cotton fields called the Old South."

Tom and Dominic are joined by Sarah Churchwell to discuss the 'Lost Cause' myth that has pervaded American culture for 150 years, its embodiment in both the novel and film version of *Gone with the Wind*, and what insight it gives into post-Civil War America.

title: RIHC: Dinosaur auctions, Dominic vs. Nick Griffin, and Singapore
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic for the latest RIHC bonus episode where they discuss Tom's triumphant purchase of a dinosaur at auction, Dominic's new enemy, and the history of Singapore.

title: RIHC: American Civil War & Stonehenge (Livestream)
cleaned_description:
Catch up on yesterday evening's livestream in audio format here. Tom and Dominic discuss the American Civil War, Stonehenge, and why Britain is so obsessed with looking to the US.

To catch up on YouTube, simply head to the following link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xc91bJeGeJs

title: American Civil War: Aftermath & Legacy (Ep 4)
cleaned_description: In the final episode of this 'American Civil War' series, Tom, Dominic, and historian Adam Smith look at the end of the conflict, the subsequent assassination of Abraham Lincoln, and how the war is viewed in modern-day America.

title: American Civil War: Gettysburg (Ep 3)
cleaned_description: Tom, Dominic, and historian Adam Smith look at the most famous battle of the war and Abraham Lincoln’s 272-word address that became one of the best-known speeches of all time. They also discuss the conditions of the black population during the conflict.

title: American Civil War: Outbreak (Ep 2)
cleaned_description:
Welcome to the second episode in The Rest Is History's 'American Civil War' series.

In today's episode, Dominic, Tom, and historian Adam Smith discuss the opening exchanges of the war and the tactics both sides used. They also look at some of the key figures, including Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson, and explore whether there was ever a realistic chance of European nations joining the conflict.

title: American Civil War: The Causes (Ep 1)
cleaned_description:
Welcome to The Rest Is History 'American Civil War' series.

In the first of four episodes, Tom and Dominic are joined by historian Adam Smith for an in-depth look at the origins of the war. They ask whether the moral, political, and economic problems of slavery made conflict inevitable and discuss the character of Abraham Lincoln.

title: Stonehenge
cleaned_description:
On today's episode, Tom and Dominic are joined by Stonehenge expert Mike Pitts to discuss all the big questions that surround Stonehenge: 

Who built it? How did they build it? What was it built for?

title: RIHC: Top Gun, Love Island, and Cicero
cleaned_description: Tom shares his excitement over the upcoming Love Island episode of The Rest Is History. Dominic discusses how Top Gun helped him get through his A-levels, and both explore the great Roman figures that featured in the story of Cleopatra.

title: ARCHIVE: Watergate (Part 2)
description:
Watergate 50th Anniversary re-release (Part 2):

Last October we recorded a two part special on the remarkable political story which became known as Watergate.

Today marks 50 years since the break-in at the Democratic headquarters in the Watergate building in Washington, D.C. - which marked the start of a scandal that would ultimately unseat US president Richard Nixon.

So we thought we’d re-release our two episodes, largely for the benefit of the many new listeners who have been kind enough to subscribe to The Rest is History over the past eight or nine months and may have missed the shows first time round.

That’s not to say our longer-standing listeners should ignore them, they certainly reward a second hearing.

Enjoy the show.

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Cleopatra's Downfall (Episode 4)
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic for the fourth and final installment in their Cleopatra mini-series, as they discuss Octavian's propaganda, the war he waged against Mark Antony and Cleopatra, and their ultimate demise.

title: Antony & Cleopatra (Episode 3)
cleaned_description: After centuries of Cleopatra and Mark Antony’s relationship being told and fictionalized by Plutarch and Shakespeare alike, Tom Holland and Dominic Sandbrook uncover what history tells us about this power couple. They reveal how the rise of Octavian as a threat caused Mark Antony to turn to Cleopatra for support. It was a relationship that had less to do with romance and love, and more to do with monetary and territory gains.

title: Julius Caesar & Cleopatra (Episode 2)
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic for the second episode of this four-part mini-series on Cleopatra, where they discuss her relationship with Julius Caesar and the role this relationship played in the politics of Rome.

title: The First Fascist
description:
Tom Holland and Dominic Sandbrook discuss the 'first' fascist, Gabriele D'Annunzio, with historian Lucy Hughes-Hallett.

D'Annunzio was a key figure in Italian literature before becoming a political figure later in his life. Although never personally identifying with fascism, his ideas were hugely influential on Mussolini.

title: How Prime Ministers Fall
cleaned_description: As British PM Boris Johnson survives a no confidence vote, Tom and Dominic record a special episode on the history of bringing down Prime Ministers. Prominent victims include Asquith, Chamberlain, Thatcher, and Blair.

title: Robin Hood
cleaned_description:
Join Tom Holland and Dominic Sandbrook as they uncover the origins of Robin Hood.

What was the earliest mention of Robin Hood in text? How has Robin Hood evolved through time to become the legend that he is today? Did he have a real-life counterpart?

title: Childbirth
description:
In today's episode, Tom and Dominic talk to Sara Read about the history of childbirth.

Sara unveils the origin of the word 'gossip' and its connection to midwifery. As well as this, they discuss how someone would qualify as a midwife; the relationship between religion and childbirth; and the average age of becoming a first time mother. They also look into the changes in the maternal mortality rate throughout history. And, finally, they touch on the authenticity of 'Call The Midwife'.  

Sara Read is the author of two works of historical fiction: The Gossips' Choice and The Midwife's Truth, available from all good bookshops.

Editor: Scarlett Murray
Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producer: Jack Davenport

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: RIHC: Boring Monarchs, The New York Times, and Dominic Sandbrook's Pleasure Island
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic for the latest bonus episode of The Rest is History Club, where they discuss what makes places in the UK deserving of city status, Britain's most boring monarchs, and the problem with The New York Times.

description:

title: Jubilees
cleaned_description: In today's episode of The Rest Is History, Dominic and Tom look at how Jubilees have served as a moment for Britain to stop and reflect. From the celebrations of George III, Queen Victoria, and George V to the modern jamborees of Elizabeth II, here's all you need to know before this year's Platinum Jubilee.

title: Australian Prime Ministers: Bob Hawke - Scott Morrison
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic for the final episode of their Antipodean epic. Tune in to hear about the exploits of the most recent stretch of prime ministers, spanning from Bob Hawke to Scott Morrison.

title: Australian Prime Ministers: Harold Holt - Malcolm Fraser
cleaned_description: In the second part of our Australian PMs trilogy, Tom and Dominic explore Chinese Communist conspiracy theories and discuss the most entertaining of all the Aussie leaders.

title: Australian Prime Ministers: Edmund Barton - Robert Menzies
cleaned_description:
In the wake of Anthony Albanese's victory in this weekend's Australian election, Tom and Dominic have recorded a three-part Antipodean special on the history of Australian prime ministers.

The first episode begins in 1901 with Edmund Barton, covers both World Wars, and explores the premierships of Robert Menzies.

title: The New Elizabethan Age
cleaned_description:
The longest reigning monarch in British history, Elizabeth II acceded to the throne 70 years ago.

To mark the occasion, Tom and Dominic are joined by Frances Christie, Deputy Chairman of Sotheby's UK and Ireland, who specializes in 20th century British art and culture. Together they explore some of the cultural, artistic, and historic happenings that have taken place during the Queen's reign.

title: RIHC: Pub Quizzes, Unstoppable Podcast Guests, and the Most Brutal Nations in History
cleaned_description: In this bonus episode, Tom and Dominic ponder who would be 'history's top hunks and babes' for an episode of Love Island. They discuss the pitfalls of being an academic compared to the freedom of being history enthusiasts. Dominic shares the dates his thirteen-year-old self thought were the most important in history. They answer questions on Hiroshima, cancel culture, and the brutality of different time periods. Finally, Tom and Dominic discover which Hogwarts houses they belong to.

title: Agatha Christie
cleaned_description:
Agatha Christie is the best-selling novelist in history.

Coinciding with the 'Wagatha Christie' trial between Coleen Rooney and Rebekah Vardy in the UK, Tom and Dominic examine Christie as a reflection of the 20th century, discuss insights about Christianity and the concept of 'evil' from her work, and debate the value of Tom's Poirot impression.

title: RIHC: Dwile flonking, Anglo-Saxons, and the sober historian
cleaned_description: Join Tom and Dominic for the latest bonus episode of The Rest Is History Club, where they talk about the art of dwile flonking, Operation Barbarossa, and the crazy scenes at the Los Angeles Review of Books.

title: History's Biggest Questions with Dan Carlin (Part 2)
cleaned_description:
Could the West have lost the Cold War? Would we be happier if we didn't study history? Would you prefer to have a samurai, a Viking, or a Spartan as your bodyguard?

Tom and Dominic are joined by Hardcore History's Dan Carlin for a second episode to tackle the biggest questions in history. 

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: History's Biggest Questions with Dan Carlin (Part 1)
cleaned_description:
Who was the most influential leader of the 20th century? What would have happened if the South had won the American Civil War? Would you rather be under siege from the Mongols, the Romans, or the Assyrians?

In a significant moment for transatlantic history podcasting, Tom and Dominic are joined by Dan Carlin, the host of one of the world's largest history podcasts, Hardcore History.

Over the course of two episodes, Dan, Tom, and Dominic tackle ten of the biggest questions in history, including counterfactuals and hypothetical matchups.

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Operation Barbarossa
cleaned_description:
What military parallels does Putin's invasion of Ukraine have with Hitler's attempt to invade the Soviet Union?

On today's episode, Tom and Dominic are joined by historian James Holland to discuss Operation Barbarossa and the Nazi invasion of 1941, whether it was doomed to fail, and the role it played in the escalation of the Holocaust.

title: RIHC: Biff & Chip, Dominic vs. Science, and The Divine Comedy
cleaned_description:
Join Tom and Dominic for this week's bonus episode where they discuss Biff & Chip, why Dominic prefers history to science, and your reaction to the latest episodes. 

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: The Birth of Babylon
cleaned_description:
In January 2022, Tom and Dominic explored the history of Babylon, from Nebuchadnezzar onwards. At the end of that episode, there was a promise to revisit Babylon's earlier period to fully do the topic justice - so here it is!

Tune in to hear about the constant theft of the Statue of Marduk, the formidable Assyrians, and what Dominic describes as his 'favourite impersonation ever.'

title: England & Englishness
description:
George Orwell, a love of wildlife, and Raheem Sterling - but what does it mean to be English in the modern world?

In today's episode, Tom and Dominic are joined by the New Statesman editor, Jason Cowley, to discuss England and Englishness in the 20th century.

Jason's new book 'Who Are We Now?' is available at all good book retailers.

Editorial Assistant: Grace Mainwaring

cleaned_description:

What makes a hero? How have heroes changed? Who will the heroes be of the future?

title: French Presidents: 1981-2022
cleaned_description:
In the second of two episodes covering France's post-war presidents, Tom and Dominic drill down into the remaining historical statesmen, bringing us right up to the current day.

François Mitterrand, Jacques Chirac, Nicolas Sarkozy, François Hollande, and Emmanuel Macron - there are some incredible stories...

title: French Presidents: 1958-1981
cleaned_description:
It's the day after the French election runoff between Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen, so here's a Rest Is History French Presidents special.

Charles de Gaulle, Georges Pompidou, and Valéry Giscard d'Estaing. Join Tom and Dominic for the first of two episodes on the topic, as they dive headfirst into the first three post-war presidents.

Join us for the second part of this special double-bill, where we'll cover the remaining historical residents of the Élysée Palace.

title: RIHC: Dominic on Disney, Tom's time machine, and Brazilian witch doctors
cleaned_description:
Dominic is back from his visit to the US, much to Tom's delight.

Tune in to hear about his travels, Tom's technical disaster, and plenty of historical discussion that ranges from the Crucifixion to the Cultural Revolution.

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: The Jewish Revolt
cleaned_description:
In the second of two episodes on the Jewish Revolt, Tom and Dominic discuss the burning of the Temple, Vespasian and Titus' triumph, and Masada.

Why was it such a landmark revolt for both Christianity and Judaism? What happened in its aftermath? And what has its historical significance been in the modern world?

All this and more on today's episode of The Rest Is History.

title: The Jews Against Rome
cleaned_description:
"The destruction of Jerusalem by the Romans: a thrilling, terrible, and blood-soaked story."

Following on from last week's episode on the Crucifixion, Tom and Dominic take us back to Judea to dissect the tumultuous events of the Jewish Revolt.

Tune in to hear the first part of the incredible story that features Pontius Pilate, Nero, and the figure of Jesus - plus how it all tenuously links to Bryan Adams and the Summer of '69.

title: Crucifixion
cleaned_description:
Crucifixions were a form of public execution so heinous that the Romans themselves were reluctant to document their gory details.

In this Easter special, Tom and Dominic trace the origins and evolution of crucifixion, as well as the historical accuracy of Jesus' death.

Warning: this pod is not for the faint of heart.

title: RIHC: Our greatest ever guest
description: With Dominic enjoying Disneyland, producer Jack joins Tom to discuss the podcast’s origin, plans for the future, and react to the recent episode on the Cultural Revolution.
cleaned_description: Jack joins Tom to discuss the podcast’s origin, plans for the future, and react to the recent episode on the Cultural Revolution.

title: Merlin, Magic and the British
description:
Richard II, Prince Charles, and Tony Blair. From Merlin, to the middle ages to the modern day, the mysterious world of magic, necromancy and the occult has had a notable presence in the lives of British monarchs, politicians and members of high society. 

Tom and Dominic are joined by Francis Young, author of 'Magic in Merlin's Realm: A History of Occult Politics in Britain' to discuss this infinitely interesting and entertaining topic.

title: Chairman Mao and the Cultural Revolution
description: China's Cultural Revolution under Chairman Mao was one of the most staggeringly brutal events in recent human history. Tom and Dominic are joined by historian Rana Mitter, who specialises in the history of Republican China.

title: The Falklands War: Afterlife (Ep 4)
cleaned_description: In the final part of our Falklands series, Tom and Dominic discuss the legacy of the war in both the UK and Argentina, and debate whether the nostalgic sentiment inspired by Britain’s victory laid the foundations for Brexit.

title: The Falklands War: Battle for the Islands (Ep 3)
cleaned_description:
In the third episode of our Falklands War mini-series, the story heats up.

The most controversial episode of the war, the sinking of the Belgrano, takes place, the British Task Force lands, and battle plays out.

Tom and Dominic thumb through their copies of the Sun, relive Reagan's final plea to Thatcher, and recount the stories of the men on the ground as Britain closed in on victory.

title: The Falklands War: The Task Force Sails (Ep 2)
description:
In the second episode of our Falklands War mini-series, Britain is faced with an Argentine occupation and prepares to go to war.

Margaret Thatcher discovers her inner Winston Churchill - but faces a titanic showdown in Parliament, which sits on a Saturday for the first time since Suez.

The Task Force eventually sails - to huge public support - while the US, France and Chile all lend a hand. 

Come for Tom's Iron Lady impression, stay for his Tony Benn as Dominic talks us through the second instalment in this epic four-parter.

Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producers: Jack Davenport & Tony Pastor

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

title: The Falklands War: Countdown to Invasion (Ep 1)
cleaned_description:
Welcome to our mini-series on The Falklands War, where Tom and Dominic will break down the causes, conflict, and aftermath of the war on its fortieth anniversary.

In the first episode, we dig into the history of the islands, the causes behind the Argentine invasion, and the domestic situation in both Britain and Argentina in the late 70s and early 80s.

The hosts also dissect the almost farcical events that took place in the buildup, some of the memorable characters like Rex Hunt, and the significance of a reindeer barbecue in South Georgia.

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Oil: Conflict, Chaos and Climate Change
description:
PART 2.

Tom and Dominic are back with Helen Thompson for a second episode on the history of oil, its impact and how it shapes geopolitics.

Tune in to hear about the impact of oil production on US Politics, its importance to the history and current situation in Ukraine and what we can learn about oil from the exploits of J. R. Ewing in the TV show 'Dallas'.

The pod also looks to the future, examining China's explosive growth and advantageous position with Green Energy, whether Putin's recent actions have shifted the basis of his geopolitical power and if Britain is on track for Net Zero by 2050...

Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producer: Jack Davenport

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Oil: The Making of the Modern World
description:
PART 1.

Tom and Dominic are joined by Helen Thompson, Professor of Political Economy at the University of Cambridge, to talk about the incredible influence of oil over the last couple of centuries.

Discussion covers the first oil well ever drilled, how it's hard to overestimate Hitler's obsession with oil, and the formation of OPEC in the aftermath of the Suez Crisis.

Helen's new book 'Disorder: Hard Times in the 21st Century' is out now.

Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producer: Jack Davenport

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

title: RIHC: Castaway Tom in Greece, Belgium vs. Burgundy, and misleading travel guides
cleaned_description:
Tom and Dominic are back with a bonus episode for all friends of the show!

The boys talk about the worst places they've ever visited, how progressive travel guides can be misleading, and the problem with 'single theory' history books.

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Genghis Khan: Lord of the Mongols
cleaned_description:
PART 2.  
'An almost sacral figure' in the words of Tom Holland, Genghis Khan has become the paramount leader of the Mongols.  

Can we call his kingdom a 'Mongol Empire'? What was his aim? And why are some now calling him an 'eco-warrior'?!

title: The Rise of Genghis Khan
cleaned_description:
PART 1.  
Tom Holland and Dominic Sandbrook speak to Ali Ansari about the origins of one of the greatest warlords in human history - Genghis Khan.  

They discuss his early life as Temujin and how he became Genghis Khan, leader of the Mongols.  

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Saint Patrick
description:
Happy St. Patrick's Day! 

No, Tom isn't turning Brixton's River Effra green, nor is Dominic distributing shamrocks throughout the Oxfordshire countryside, but they're here anyway with a very special pod on the mysterious Apostle of Ireland. 

When was St. Patrick alive? Where was he really born? Why was he kidnapped by pirates? And did he really banish the snakes from Ireland?

All this and more on today's episode of The Rest Is History.

Producer: Dom Johnson

Exec Producer: Jack Davenport

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: RIHC: The 'Dark Ages' (Livestream)
cleaned_description:
Tom and Dominic dive into the mysterious era referred to by many as the 'Dark Ages' in their livestream to the RIHC on Tuesday, 15th March.

The pair explore the death of Roman civilization, the rising dominance of the Islamic empire, and the obliteration of paganism, while debating whether it’s a good idea to take a shot every time Tom mentions Christianity.

Watch the YouTube version here: https://youtu.be/B0ExTJL1wh0?t=324

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: The Last Emperor of Mexico
cleaned_description:
What links the Mexican Republic, Palmerston, the Hapsburgs, Napoleon III, and butterfly catching? The answer is the incredible story of the Last Emperor of Mexico.

Tom and Dominic are joined by Edward Shawcross as they travel back to recount and discuss this amazing moment in Mexican history.

title: RIHC: Top 10 UK PMs, Dominic Cummings in Russia and a tribute to Shane Warne
cleaned_description:
Tom's woken Dominic up at the crack of dawn on a Monday morning to record the bonus podcast!

Tune in to find out who's more of a morning person, what Dominic Cummings was doing in Russia in the 90s, and who Dominic thinks is the UK's greatest ever Prime Minister (hint: it's not Stanley Baldwin).

title: Putin's Russia (Episode 4)
description:
[Episode 4 of 4]

'In the noughties, Russian democracy becomes a form of show business'

In the final instalment of our Russia mini-series, Tom and Dominic reach the climax of Putin’s rise to power, charting how a former KGB agent managed to climb from relative obscurity to become the uncrowned Tsar of Russia.

The episode also touches on his relationship with oligarchs such as Roman Abramovich, the hall of mirrors he's created, and a look at how his character has changed over the course of his presidency.

Editor: Vasco Andrade
Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producers: Tony Pastor & Jack Davenport

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory

@dcsandbrook

title: Yeltsin, Economic Chaos and President Putin (Episode 3)
cleaned_description:
[Episode 3 of 4]

"You certainly won't understand what ordinary Russians see in Vladimir Putin if you don't understand what happened in the 1990s. A time of utter, utter collapse."

In part three of our Soviet Union, Russia and Putin series, Tom and Dominic drill down into the details of the chaos in 90s Russia, the laughing stock Yeltsin became on the global stage, and Putin's brutal rise to power on the back of the Second Chechen War. 

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: The Fall of the Soviet Empire (Episode 2)
description:
[Episode 2 of 4]

This episode of The Rest Is History marks the second instalment in our four part series on the Soviet Union, Russia and the rise of Vladimir Putin.

From the 70th anniversary of the Russian Revolution in 1987 to the fall of the Soviet Union on Christmas Day 1991, this episode is jam-packed full of late Soviet drama. 

Tune in now to hear about the abuse Yeltsin received after his attempted suicide, the failed Soviet coup of 1991 and Putin's return from East Germany. 

Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producers: Tony Pastor & Jack Davenport

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Young Putin, the KGB and the Soviet Union (Episode 1)
description:
[Episode 1 of 4]

Welcome to our new four part series on the latter years of the Soviet Union, its fall, Putin's early life and his subsequent rise to power.

Today's episode focuses on Brezhnev, Putin's formative years, his early KGB career and Gorbachev's descent into chaos.

Was Putin a nationalist or a communist? What changed from Brezhnev to Gorbachev? What was Putin doing in East Germany during the Soviet twilight years?

Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producers: Tony Pastor & Jack Davenport

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

title: Killer Fashion
cleaned_description:
How much do you know about the lethal price people have paid over the centuries to look fashionable?

In today's episode, Tom and Dominic are joined by Dr. Alison Matthews David to discuss the dark secrets behind the history of garments.

title: RIHC: Zelenskyy, le Carré and Tom's drive from Hamburg to Berlin
cleaned_description:
Tune in to this week's bonus episode to hear a classic ramble chat between Tom and Dominic.

The boys discuss the career of Volodymyr Zelenskyy, how well Dominic would fare on Strictly, and what stood out for Tom during his drive from Hamburg to Berlin after the fall of the Berlin Wall.

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Byzantium and the Ghosts of Rome (Part 2)
cleaned_description:
What happened to Rome after its fall?

In the second of two episodes on the fall of the Roman Empire, Tom and Dominic discuss where Rome endured, how its ghost still haunts 21st century geopolitics, and which member of the British Royal Family Tom thinks is the last true Roman!

title: When did the Roman Empire fall? (Part 1)
cleaned_description: Tom and Dominic explore what Edward Gibbon called “the greatest, perhaps, and most awful scene in the history of mankind”: the decline and fall of the Roman Empire.

title: RIHC: Dominic Sandbrook - This Is Your Life (Livestream)
cleaned_description:
Catch up on last night's livestream in audio form to learn about all things Sandbrook: his early life, schooling and university, historical influences, stag weekends in far-flung lands, and much more.

To take full advantage of the media elements referenced in the stream, watch the video version and skip to 6:58 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZapgkOVOokY.

Have a great weekend!

title: Ukraine and Russia
description: With eastern Europe apparently on the brink of war and Vladimir Putin citing history as pretext, what exactly is Ukraine? Is it distinct from Russia, and how long has it existed? Tom and Dominic run through a brutal and fractured history, from the Viking conquest and Kyivan Rus', to the ever-shifting landscape in the early modern period, to the incredibly complicated Russian Civil War, right up to the modern day.
cleaned_description: With Eastern Europe apparently on the brink of war and Vladimir Putin citing history as a pretext, what exactly is Ukraine? Is it distinct from Russia, and how long has it existed? Tom and Dominic explore a brutal and fractured history, from the Viking conquest and Kyivan Rus' to the ever-shifting landscape in the early modern period, the incredibly complicated Russian Civil War, and up to the modern day.

title: ARCHIVE: The Vikings and the birth of Kyiv
cleaned_description: Want to know more about the history of the Vikings in the East and how it relates to modern-day Russia and Ukraine? Listen to our episode on the topic, where Tom and Dominic drill down into the birth of Kyiv.

title: ARCHIVE: Ukraine and the United Kingdom
cleaned_description: With Russia seemingly on the brink of invading Ukraine, here's an episode from our archives on the historical relationship between the UK and Ukraine, recorded during last year's European football championships.

title: The Most Disastrous Party in History
cleaned_description:
We've all been to some terrible parties, but what is the most disastrous party in human history? 

Not at all inspired by recent political events, Tom and Dominic have narrowed down listener suggestions to the ten parties they think are the most calamitous. Tune in to hear which party comes out on top!

title: God and the American Empire
cleaned_description:
On today's episode, Tom and Dominic are joined by Professor Andrew Preston to discuss the relationship between the US and religion, both at home and abroad in the 20th and 21st centuries.

Why have there been such low levels of anti-clericalism in the US compared to the rest of the world? What's behind the sustained and growing numbers of religious believers in the United States? Was the Cold War really a religious crusade against godless communism?

Tune in to hear the discussion on American Exceptionalism, the Marketplace of Faith, and whether 'US isolationism' is an ahistorical term.

title: American Crusades
cleaned_description:
On today's episode, Tom and Dominic are joined by Andrew Preston, a Cambridge University professor whose new book focuses on religion in American war and diplomacy.

What is the role of religion in the American outlook? How has it shaped foreign policy? What is the relationship between pacifistic religious ideals and a crusading mentality?

Join us tomorrow for another episode, which focuses on more recent American history and its relationship with religion.

title: RIHC: Clement Attlee's taxi, Tom's waning whiggery and Farewell to the Horse
cleaned_description:
Join Tom and Dominic for this week's RIHC bonus episode where they discuss Churchill's legacy, Piers Morgan's Daily Mirror, how Charles I was just Harold Macmillan, and Tom's faithless whiggery. 

This, plus all the discord japes and as many members' questions as possible.

title: Valentine's Day
cleaned_description:
Happy Valentine's Day! Have you ever wondered why we send each other cards and go out to dinner on a weeknight?

In today's episode, Tom and Dominic drill down into the details—what are its origins? Why were 'Vinegar' Valentines so brutal? And what was an optician's role in Al Capone's St. Valentine's Day Massacre?

title: Smuggling
cleaned_description:
Did you think smuggling in Britain was confined to the Jamaica Inn and the beaches of the Cornish coast? If so, you might want to listen to today's podcast, where Tom and Dominic are joined by author and smuggling expert, Alex Preston.

The discussion is wide-ranging, including wrecking, the Hawkhurst Gang, and coastal militias.

Alex's new book, Winchelsea, is available at all good book retailers.

title: RIHC: The Trial of Capel Lofft
description:
The Rumble in the Jungle. The Thrilla in Manila. The King in the Ring. 

Today's bonus podcast is a special one: Frenemy of the Show, Capel Lofft, defends the dignity and honour of Charles I (King and Martyr) against Tom and Dominic, his Whiggish foes.

There are huge twists, unbelievable revelations and plenty of good humoured jousting. 

It's liquid history at its best. Wangs: sit back, drink it in and enjoy.

Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producer: Jack Davenport

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: The Birth of Russia
cleaned_description: In the second of two episodes on the Vikings in the East, Tom and Dominic investigate their role in the birth of Russia.

title: The Vikings Go East
cleaned_description: In this week's episode, Tom and Dominic take a look at the actions, influence, and brutalization of the Vikings in Eastern Europe, including their role in the formation of Russia and Ukraine.

title: Disease, the New World and modern pandemics (Part 2)
cleaned_description:
How devastating were European arrivals to the Americas in terms of deaths and the introduction of new infectious diseases?

Tom and Dominic are joined by Professor Kyle Harper from the University of Oklahoma to discuss the relationship between disease and colonial expansion, the origins of the Spanish flu, and the spread of modern forms of infectious disease.

title: Disease vs. the rise of civilisation (Part 1)
description:
The way we die has been utterly transformed.

There have been around 10,000 generations of human beings, but only in the last 3 or 4 have infectious diseases not been an expected and accepted cause of death.

What drove the most deadly infectious diseases? Was technological progress and globalisation one of the key causes for its spread over the course of history?

Tom and Dominic are joined by Professor Kyle Harper from the University of Oklahoma to discuss the fascinating history of disease and how shifts in the way we die have changed our world completely.

Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producer: Tony Pastor

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: RIHC: David Cameron's scotch eggs, Charles I's bedfellows and a tribute to Boney M.
cleaned_description:
In this week's bonus podcast, Tom and Dominic discuss episode reactions, members' questions, and the latest discord musings. The boys also talk about the doppelgängers of David Cameron and George Osborne, what makes a civil war a civil war, and Charles I's historical bedfellows. 

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Babylon
cleaned_description:
Greatest city on earth. Den of iniquity. Imperial oppressor. Wealth and power.

The ancient city of Babylon has been mythologized for millennia, but how much do we actually know and why does it still resonate today?

title: RIHC: Reputations (Livestream)
description:
Did you miss last night's livestream on Reputations or simply want to listen again? You're in luck!

Tune in to hear impressions, reputational musings and members' questions aplenty.

Thanks to all those who were in attendance yesterday and to those who helped crash Discord before!

title: The Trial of Charles I Part 2
cleaned_description:
Tune in to hear the second part of The Rest Is History's take on the execution of Charles I and its aftermath.

Charles I was executed 373 years ago to the day on 30th January. But was his killing a sinful act of treason or merely one of retributive justice?

Tom and Dominic welcome back Professor Ted Vallance from the University of Roehampton to explore one of the most extraordinary events in British history.

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: The Trial of Charles I Part 1
cleaned_description:
Charles I was executed 373 years ago to the day on 30th January. But was his killing a sinful act of treason or merely one of retributive justice?

Tom and Dominic welcome back Professor Ted Vallance from the University of Roehampton to explore the build-up, event, and aftermath of the trial of Charles I.

title: General Gordon and the Siege of Khartoum
cleaned_description:
What happened to Gordon at Khartoum?

Described by Dominic as the 'greatest media event of the Victorian era', this second part is not to be missed.

title: General Gordon: The Ultimate Victorian Hero
cleaned_description:
Who was General Gordon? 

Tune in to hear about the life and times of the 'emblematic martyr of the Victorian age'.

title: The Birth of the Railways
cleaned_description:
Today, Tom and Dominic are joined by historian Dan Jackson to talk about one of the greatest inventions known to man - the railways.

Where were they first created? When did they arrive in England? And how did they relate to the standardisation of GMT in Britain?

From Eric Hobsbawm to cucumber straighteners, this episode has it all! 

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: RIHC: Augustus, Appeasement, and a life of hiccups
cleaned_description: In this week's bonus podcast, Tom and Dominic discuss episode reactions, members' questions, and your latest Discord musings. The boys also talk about how appeasement informed later British foreign policy, the corrupting impact of gold in the Roman Republic, and why Kevin Keegan and Tony Blair's game of headers was straight out of the Augustus playbook.

title: The Princes in the Tower Part 2
description:
Who killed the Princes in the Tower? The inspiration behind Shakespeare's Richard III, their murder remains one of the greatest mysteries in English history. 

In the second of two episodes, all eyes turn to Richard III, prime suspect in the disappearance of Edward IV's sons. 

Tom and Dominic discuss whether Richard likely did kill his nephews, potential other suspects, and whether it was a matter of survival for him to do so.

Plus, the greatest question of our time: was Richard III more Raul Castro, Robert Kennedy, or James Callaghan?

Producer: Dom Johnson
Exec Producer: Tony Pastor

Twitter:
@TheRestHistory
@holland_tom
@dcsandbrook

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: The Princes in the Tower Part 1
cleaned_description:
Who killed the Princes in the Tower? The inspiration behind Shakespeare's Richard III, their murder is one of the greatest mysteries in English history.

In the first of two episodes, we start with the princes' father, Edward IV. Tom and Dominic discuss the remarkable parallels between Edward IV and his grandson, Henry VIII, and why Edward's brother, Duke of Clarence, is certainly not a friend of the show.

All this, plus Tom's case for why he does a better prince impression than Brian Blessed.

title: 1922: The Birth of the Modern World Part 2
cleaned_description:
In part 2 of this centennial episode, Tom and Dominic cover the triggering of the Irish Civil War, the birth of the BBC, and Howard Carter's 'Tutmania'. 

Plus, have you ever wondered how many stars Dominic's 1995 Edinburgh Fringe performance of Becket REALLY received from The Scotsman? Featuring appearances from Winston Churchill, Michael Collins, and Just William, this podcast is not to be missed!

title: 1922: The Birth of the Modern World Part 1
cleaned_description: 2022 marks 100 years since one of the most important years in modern history. In part 1, Tom and Dominic discuss all things 1922: Bolshevism, fascism, and the significance of The Waste Land and Ulysses.

title: RIHC: Ian Paisley vs. Otto von Habsburg, horse riding in the Wild West, and why Margaret Thatcher went into politics
cleaned_description:
In this week's bonus podcast, Tom and Dominic discuss your reactions, questions, and latest discord japes. The boys also talk about Ian Paisley receiving a beating in the European Parliament, sing a duet together, and argue over which British and American leaders really believed in the binary battle between good and evil. 

Email: restishistorypod@gmail.com

title: Crossing the Rubicon
description: Julius Caesar upended the Roman Republic on this day (maybe) over 2000 years ago. Tom explains everything that led up to the moment and what made Caesar's decision to march his legion back into Italy so seismic.
cleaned_description: Julius Caesar upended the Roman Republic on this day (maybe) over 2000 years ago. Tom explains everything that led up to the moment and what made Caesar's decision to march his legion back into Italy so seismic.

In a live show recorded in Leicester Square, London, Tom and Dominic discuss the relationship between history and cinema through the years.

title: RIHC: Introducing the '12' Days of Christmas
cleaned_description: Merry Christmas, members of the Rest Is History Club! Instead of our normal schedule, Dominic and Tom have recorded 13 episodes remembering events that have happened on this day in history from Christmas Day up to the 6th of January. As a club member, you have early access to all 13 episodes to listen to at your leisure over the holiday period. The next bonus episode will be available on 3rd January (our live show on cinema and history), and our regular schedule will resume on 10th January.

title: 6 Jan: Alfred the Great and Pepys' 'Fanatiques'
description: A key battle in the history of England and a forgotten uprising in 17th century London round off our 12 (13) Days of Christmas. Back with to our regular schedule next Monday 10th January.
cleaned_description: A key battle in the history of England and a forgotten uprising in 17th century London round off our 12 Days of Christmas. Back to our regular schedule next Monday, January 10th.

description: The catalyst for the upheaval of 1066 and one of the most controversial episodes in French history happened on this day in history.

title: 4 Jan: Solomon Northup and Albert Camus
description: Tom analyses the historical importance of Solomon Northup's story, made famous by Steve McQueen's '12 Years A Slave'. Then, Dominic delves into the death of French philosopher and author Albert Camus. Tune in to also hear about the travails of Monsieur Sandbrook, the 21-year-old Provence-based English language assistant.

description: It's New Year's Eve - switch off the Hootenanny and tune in to hear Dominic recount extraordinary tales of coups, cousins and the rise of an emperor in the Central African Republic. Later on in the podcast, Tom questions whether the current pandemic will have a more prominent role in the history books than the often disregarded Spanish flu.
